item.title: Coronavirus: UK authorises anti-viral drug remdesivir
item.description: Remdesivir shortens recovery time by about four days, research suggests.

item.title: Coronavirus: Local lockdowns will be used to suppress 'flare-ups', says Hancock
item.description: The health secretary says coronavirus restrictions are part of plans to suppress infections in England.

item.title: Dominic Cummings: Minister Douglas Ross quits over senior aide's lockdown actions
item.description: Douglas Ross quits the government as more than 35 Conservative MPs call for Dominic Cummings to go.

item.title: Four Minnesota cops fired after death of unarmed black man
item.description: The FBI investigates Minneapolis police after video shows man being arrested saying "I can't breathe".

item.title: Coronavirus: Nurse and doctor wed in hospital where they work
item.description: Jann Tipping and Annalan Navaratnam were given special permission for the ceremony in London.

item.title: Coronavirus: One week in one hospital
item.description: The BBC has been given unprecedented access to a hospital in the heart of London, for one week.

item.title: Coronavirus: France announces â‚¬8bn rescue plan for car industry
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron wants France to become the top producer of clean vehicles in Europe.

item.title: Lori Klausutis death: Twitter will not remove Trump's 'horrifying lies'
item.description: The company says it is "deeply sorry" for the pain caused by the tweets about a woman's 2001 death.

item.title: Coronavirus: John Lewis plans phased reopening of stores
item.description: Shops in England will start to reopen next week, but will customers return or stick to online ordering?

item.title: JK Rowling unveils The Ickabog, her first non-Harry Potter children's book
item.description: The Ickabog is her first non-Harry Potter children's story, and will be published in instalments.

item.title: Labour names David Evans as new general secretary
item.description: The party's new most senior official was assistant general secretary between 1999 and 2001.

item.title: Glastonbury: BBC to air classic sets in festival's absence
item.description: The corporation will air historic sets after the festival was cancelled amid the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: East Finchley big cat scare: Armed police called to garden
item.description: The feline turned out to be an exotic pet which posed no risk to the public, Scotland Yard says.

item.title: Costa Rica celebrates first same-sex weddings
item.description: The country is the first in Central America to allow same-sex couples to marry in landmark ruling.

item.title: Coronavirus: Jamaican bobsleigh team in Peterborough Mini push
item.description: Two team members push a Mini around Peterborough as they cannot use their training facilities.

item.title: How do you ease your dog out of lockdown?
item.description: Has your dog enjoyed your working from home too much? Separation anxiety could be an issue as the lockdown is lifted.

item.title: Gucci slashes 'stale' seasonal fashion shows
item.description: The major label is moving to only two "seasonless" collections saying clothes need a longer life.

item.title: Scrubs: A sitcom that's actually aged well?
item.description: We ask the sitcom's stars how well it holds up 20 years on.

item.title: Boy, 12, followed down mountain by brown bear
item.description: Alessandro was hiking with his family in northern Italy when they realised he was being followed.

item.title: Turner Prize 2020 axed and replaced by Â£100k fund for struggling artists
item.description: The often controversial prize is replaced by bursaries worth Â£100,000 to help struggling artists.

item.title: Covid-19 brings remote medicine revolution to the UK
item.description: Doctors are finding new ways of working including reviewing patients' scans and X-rays at home.

item.title: Thailand: Elephants on 'great migration' to survive coronavirus starvation
item.description: With the collapse of the tourism industry because of the coronavirus, Thailand's captive elephants are now at risk of starvation.

item.title: Coronavirus: Artist adds Queen in face mask to collection
item.description: Emelie Hryhoruk said We Will Meet Again "shows everyone is vulnerable no matter who they are".

item.title: Coronavirus: University freshers â€˜robbed of experienceâ€™
item.description: Exploring the impact of the abrupt end to university for three first year students

item.title: Indonesia: Alone in a sinking village
item.description: Once home to more than 200 families, the village of Bedono in Central Java is now under water.

item.title: Coronavirus: Window cleaner helps elderly clients through isolation
item.description: Window cleaner Vin Kennedy has been a link to the outside world for his self-isolating clients.

item.title: Is it game over for working in an office?
item.description: As companies hint at more home-working, how could our work culture be about to shift?

item.title: Italy's medical workers: 'We became heroes but they've already forgotten us'
item.description: With Italy past the peak of coronavirus, medical staff say the trauma is only just hitting them now.

item.title: Coronavirus: Can we stay safe as lockdown eases?
item.description: As lockdowns ease, what are the risks of getting infected as people come into closer contact again?

item.title: Huawei: What would happen if the UK ditched the Chinese firm?
item.description: Officials are taking another look into Huawei, but the Chinese firm warns against a 5G ban.

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: The drug combination that may help us beat Covid-19
item.description: Dr John Wright expects a treatment involving three different types of drug to be effective against the virus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Call for clear face masks to be 'the norm'
item.description: Transparent masks allow deaf people to communicate - but supplies are short where they are most needed.

item.title: Coronavirus in South Africa: Smokers fume at cigarette ban
item.description: The government is to ease lockdown restrictions and allow the sale of alcohol - but not cigarettes.

item.title: Find out which masks offer the most protection and why
item.description: You may have heard the term N95 but what does it mean and why are some masks rated higher than others?

item.title: Coronavirus: The strangers reaching out to Kyrgyzstan's lonely teenagers
item.description: Worried by teens' mental health struggles during Kyrgyzstan's coronavirus lockdown, one group acted.

item.title: Lifting Premier League trophy without fans would be 'strange' - Liverpool captain Henderson
item.description: Playing at Anfield and lifting the Premier League trophy without any fans will be "pretty strange", says Liverpool captain Jordan Henderson.

item.title: Borussia Dortmund 0-1 Bayern Munich: Joshua Kimmich sends leaders seven points clear
item.description: Leaders Bayern Munich take a big step to retaining their Bundesliga title by winning away from home at second-placed Borussia Dortmund.

item.title: Hearts propose 14-14-14 league revamp for two years
item.description: Hearts owner Ann Budge proposes a restructured SPFL of three divisions of 14 teams for the next two seasons.

item.title: Christian Mbulu: Morecambe and ex-Motherwell defender dies aged 23
item.description: Morecambe defender Christian Mbulu has died aged 23, with circumstances undisclosed.

item.title: 'World Cup final tape will never be wiped' - ex-England coach Bayliss
item.description: Former England coach Trevor Bayliss says he recorded the World Cup final win over New Zealand and it will "never be wiped".

item.title: Wednesday's gossip column: Newcastle in talks to sign Coutinho
item.description: Newcastle in talks to sign Coutinho, Magpies takeover in doubt, Arsenal and Tottenham compete for Willian, plus more.

item.title: Audi sack Abt over esports driver impersonation
item.description: Audi fire Formula E racer Daniel Abt after a professional gamer played under his name in an esports version of the series.

item.title: Dominic Cummings: Did he break lockdown rules?
item.description: The UK PM's most senior adviser has responded to accusations that he broke lockdown rules - what did he say?

item.title: Coronavirus: Can it affect eyesight?
item.description: The prime minister's chief adviser says his vision was affected by coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus pandemic: Tracking the global outbreak
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the respiratory virus has spread around the world and how it is being dealt with.

item.title: Coronavirus UK map: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: How to keep safe while shopping in a coronavirus pandemic
item.description: From one way systems to not touching everything on the shelves - shopping will look very different.

item.title: Coronavirus: What tests are being done in the UK?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: Changes have been announced to guidelines in England on exercise and social distancing.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules on caring for children during lockdown?
item.description: A look at the guidance as Downing Street backs Dominic Cummings over his 260-mile lockdown trip.

item.title: Dominic Cummings row: The families who stayed away in lockdown
item.description: Members of the public have expressed anger after the PM's chief adviser travelled to Durham in lockdown.

item.title: Dominic Cummings: Full statement on lockdown row
item.description: The PM's chief adviser told a press conference he wanted to "clear up confusion" amid calls for him to resign.

item.title: Lockdown update: All you need to know about new measures
item.description: How will social and work life be different after the easing of some restrictions in England?

item.title: Could you have to pay your bank to save money?
item.description: As countries take extreme measures keep the economy afloat, could we see negative interest rates?

item.title: Coronavirus: How does contact tracing work and is my data safe?
item.description: Millions in the UK will soon be asked to monitor who they have been near to combat coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: How safe are takeaways and supermarket deliveries?
item.description: If coronavirus can be transferred on to surfaces, what are the risks of buying food?

item.title: What's the risk on public transport?
item.description: Bus and train operators are reducing services and increasing cleaning.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK travel quarantine rules?
item.description: What do you need to know if you're planning to fly during the Covid-19 pandemic?

item.title: Coronavirus: Can children catch and pass on coronavirus?
item.description: BBC's Health Correspondent Laura Foster explains what we know currently about how children are affected by the virus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Where do governments borrow money?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Coronavirus: 'Baffling' observations from the front line
item.description: Doctors on the front lines are observing things that they have never encountered before - and it's a challenge.
